discussion.content:
I am not sure about C due to the lack of features an ISP router has....
Maybe B.

comments.content: "Disable Internet access for the IoT devices" is what kept me from choosing D. Not all IoT devices require internet access, but we don't know exactly what this user has and cutting internet access may inhibit optimum usability. For example, a "home assistant" could be an Alexa and if Alexa doesn't have WiFi access, you can't use all her features which can get annoying to many users.

discussion.content:
Maybe: D. Change all default passwords on the IoT devices, disable Internet access for the IoT devices and the home assistant, obtain routable IP addresses for all devices, and implement IPv6 and IPSec protections on all network traffic.
The CASP will be my 4th CompTIA cybersec exam. Already have sec+, cysa, and pentest. Seems to me that whenever CompTIA gives "change default password" as an option, that is the answer. That is always the first thing you do. 
Aside from that, there are a lot of good ideas in this option. Not sure why you want "routable IP addresses" but other than that.

questions.question_text:
A user asks a security practitioner for recommendations on securing a home network. The user recently purchased a connected home assistant and multiple IoT devices in an effort to automate the home. Some of the IoT devices are wearables, and other are installed in the user's automobiles. The current home network is configured as a single flat network behind an ISP-supplied router. The router has a single IP address, and the router performs NAT on incoming traffic to route it to individual devices.
Which of the following security controls would address the user's privacy concerns and provide the BEST level of security for the home network?

choices.D: Change all default passwords on the IoT devices, disable Internet access for the IoT devices and the home assistant, obtain routable IP addresses for all devices, and implement IPv6 and IPSec protections on all network traffic.
choices.B: Install a firewall capable of cryptographically separating network traffic, require strong authentication to access all IoT devices, and restrict network access for the home assistant based on time-of-day restrictions.
choices.C: Segment the home network to separate network traffic from users and the IoT devices, ensure security settings on the home assistant support no or limited recording capability, and install firewall rules on the router to restrict traffic to the home assistant as much as possible.
choices.A: Ensure all IoT devices are configured in a geofencing mode so the devices do not work when removed from the home network. Disable the home assistant unless actively using it, and segment the network so each IoT device has its own segment.

questions.question_text:
An enterprise with global sites processes and exchanges highly sensitive information that is protected under several countries' arms trafficking laws. There is new information that malicious nation-state-sponsored activities are targeting the use of encryption between the geographically disparate sites. The organization currently employs ECDSA and ECDH with P-384, SHA-384, and AES-256-GCM on VPNs between sites.
Which of the following techniques would MOST likely improve the resilience of the enterprise to attack on cryptographic implementation?

choices.A: Add a second-layer VPN from a different vendor between sites.
choices.B: Upgrade the cipher suite to use an authenticated AES mode of operation.
choices.E: Ensure cryptography modules are kept up to date from vendor supplying them.
choices.D: Implement an IDS with sensors inside (clear-text) and outside (cipher-text) of each tunnel between sites.
choices.C: Use a stronger elliptic curve cryptography algorithm.

discussion.content:
C
The answer provided is correct. The bad actors are specifically attacking the cryptography (i.e. they're factoring the key to break the cryptography). There is no way to factor large elliptical curve cryptography. You have to brute force they keys, which can take an exponentially long time. More info about elliptical curve cryptography and why it's better than diffe-hellman cryptography here:
https://blog.cloudflare.com/a-relatively-easy-to-understand-primer-on-elliptic-curve-cryptography/
the answer is A. Vendor diversity along with another layer of defense will the make it more resilient.

According to this article: https://malware.news/t/everyone-loves-curves-but-which-elliptic-curve-is-the-most-popular/17657 P-256 is the dominant ECC curve used today, and P-384 is stronger than that because of its longer key length. For this reason, I doubt the problem here is a weak ECC algorithm.

comments.content: Using the same cryptography from a different vendor is going to do absolutely nothing to protect your data payload.

discussion.content: Every other test I've used, free, or fee, describes option A with completely different wording. Rather than “The unsecure port 80 being used for general web traffic” is says “Malicious actors intercepting inbound and outbound communication to determine the scope of the mission” and indicates that as the correct answer. Don’t be shocked if this question is on the real test like that.

questions.question_text:
The government is concerned with remote military missions being negatively impacted by the use of technology that may fail to protect operational security. To remediate this concern, a number of solutions have been implemented, including the following:
✑ End-to-end encryption of all inbound and outbound communication, including personal email and chat sessions that allow soldiers to securely communicate with families.
✑ Layer 7 inspection and TCP/UDP port restriction, including firewall rules to only allow TCP port 80 and 443 and approved applications
✑ A host-based whitelist of approved websites and applications that only allow mission-related tools and sites
✑ The use of satellite communication to include multiple proxy servers to scramble the source IP address
Which of the following is of MOST concern in this scenario?

choices.B: Family members posting geotagged images on social media that were received via email from soldiers
choices.D: The use of centrally managed military network and computers by soldiers when communicating with external parties
choices.C: The effect of communication latency that may negatively impact real-time communication with mission control
choices.A: The unsecure port 80 being used for general web traffic

discussion.content: i went with C and D and, but the answer is C and E, I'm confused because the hacker used a privilage escalation attack not a buffer overflow.

Selected Answer: CD
Going with C and D due to the gpg -e and scp commands.

its C and D.
Base on log we see from jsmith>root, then scp the payrol data
I guess C & E. E because of this http://security.cs.rpi.edu/~candej2/kernel/kernel_exploit.pdf
Definitely C&D. There is no buffer overflow, the kernel panic is from trying to access an invalid pointer.

comments.content: No it’s not. There is no buffer overflow. The panic is caused by an incorrect remove command. C&D are the answers.
I think I would go with CD. I don't know that there was a buffer overflow that caused the kernel panic.

discussion.content: Why not D? Data were encrypted with GPG then copied to remote server with SCP

choices.E: Buffer overflow in memory paging caused a kernel panic
choices.D: Payroll data was exfiltrated to an attacker-controlled host
choices.C: Jsmith successfully used a privilege escalation attack
choices.B: Encrypted payroll data was successfully decrypted by the attacker
choices.F: Syslog entries were lost due to the host being rebooted
choices.A: A root user performed an injection attack via kernel module

discussion.content:
D. Improper field usage.

A developer should never store important variables locally, since it can be tampered using a HTTP Interceptor (like Burp or OWASP ZAP).
In this particular case, the attacker could modify price variable to zero, so that he wouldn’t pay anything.
It's improper field usage, just to be clear on that.
